newsitem.title: UK: TMCC's Euro-Asian bond aims for wider distribution.
newsitem.headline: TMCC's Euro-Asian bond aims for wider distribution.

text.p: Toyota Motor Credit Corp successfully expanded its investor base on Wednesday by setting a jumbo mark-denominated Euro-Asian bond, dealers said.
"A lot of institutional investors in the Far East are interested in marks and have increased their foreign currency holdings," the Merrill Lynch syndicate manager said.
"We are very pleased and could have sold more -- we sold nearly half the paper in the Far East and there was a strong bid from Switzerland," he added.

The structure -- a 1.0 billion mark five-year bond listed in Hong Kong, Singapore, Frankfurt and London -- was intended to get the best possible distribution for the borrower, syndicate officials said.

"With EMU there issuers will compete in fewer currencies in a smaller market for the same investors. So the Euro-Asian structure is a good way to position an issuer," the syndicate manager at joint lead manager Merrill Lynch in Frankfurt said.
He said the bond was one of the few liquid benchmark mark bonds in the five-year sector since June.
Ontario and Sweden have also used the Euro-Asian structure.
SBC Warburg was the other lead manager on the deal which was issued off an EMTN Programme.
The bond was priced to yield five basis points over the 8.25 percent September 2001 Bund.
Some new issues traders said the paper was aggressively priced but there was good demand for corporate paper.
"The bond is differentiated from the bulk of the other five-year mark deals that have been mostly retail-targeted and tightly priced," the syndicate manager at Merrill said.

Some traders said the deal put the five-year corporate mark sector under some pressure, although they were surprised at the pressure as retail investors tended to hold onto their bonds and not switch into fresh paper.
